Two bars, bar 1 and bar 2, are at rest on a smooth horizontal table as shown in the top view above. Each bar is connected to the table with a vertical pin. Bar 1 and bar 2 are made from the same material and have the same physical dimensions, but bar 1 has three additional large holes drilled through it. The two bars are each accelerated from rest by forces of equal magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> applied at their right end. The forces remain perpendicular to the bars and the forces are exerted for an equal amount of time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

(a) Briefly explain using physics principles why the angular displacement for bar 1 is larger than the angular displacement for bar 2.

This question is a short free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

(7 points, suggested time 13 minutes)

Two bars, bar 1 and bar 2, are at rest on a smooth horizontal table as shown in the top view above. Each bar is connected to the table with a vertical pin. Bar 1 and bar 2 are made from the same material and have the same physical dimensions, but bar 1 has three additional large holes drilled through it. The two bars are each accelerated from rest by forces of equal magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> applied at their right end. The forces remain perpendicular to the bars and the forces are exerted for an equal amount of time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

(a) Briefly explain using physics principles why the angular displacement for bar 1 is larger than the angular displacement for bar 2.
(b) On the axes below, sketch the angular velocity of each bar as a function of time. Label the sketch for bar 1 “Bar 1”. Label the sketch for bar 2, “Bar 2”.

(c) After the force has been applied to both bars for a time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, is the angular momentum of bar 1 larger than, smaller than, or the same as the angular momentum of bar 2?
___ Larger          ___ Smaller          ___ The same
Justify your answer.
